dialog_nodes.title: I want to be transferred to an agent

values.text: Okay, let me get you connected to one of our team members who can assist you further.

generic.title: Hi! I'm a virtual assistant powered by Watson to help answer questions about Covid-19. Here are some options you can try:

options.label: Guidance on Events and Large Gatherings

dialog_nodes.title: How should I wash my hands properly?

values.text: The CDC recommends washing your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, being sure to scrub all around and under fingernails, and finally drying with an air dryer or clean towel. If you do not have access to soap or running water, you can use a hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol concentration. You can find more information on the CDC's hand-washing recommendations here.

dialog_nodes.title: How can I prevent getting Covid-19?

values.text: Covid-19 is thought to spread mainly through person to person transmission, so it's important to distance yourself from others as much as possible to prevent getting the virus. Additionally, you should wash your hands often and avoid touching your face as much as possible. For more information, check out the CDC's guide to protecting yourself and others.

dialog_nodes.title: 8. Are you having any of these symptoms? - part2

values.text: <? $self == True ? "Are you": "Is the person of concern" ?> having any of these symptoms?

• Sore throat
  • Headache
  • Myalgias (Body aches)
  • Spitting up mucus
  • Loss of appetite
  • Fatigue
  • Dizziness
  • Nausea
  • Diarrhea
  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Altered sense of taste
  • Altered sense of smell

dialog_nodes.title: 8. Are you having any of these symptoms? - part1

values.text: <? $self == True ? "Are you": "Is the person of concern" ?> having any of these symptoms?

• Fever (Oral temperature of 100.4 or above)
  • Cough
  • Shortness of breath

dialog_nodes.title: How long can I get paid sick leave if I have Covid 19?

values.text:
The Families First Coronavirus Response Act (FFCRA) requires that certain employers give two weeks (up to 80 hours) of paid leave to employees experiencing Covid-19 symptoms and seeking a medical diagnosis.
Additionally, if you are unable to work because you are caring for someone with Covid-19 or have a child whose school was closed, you may be eligible for additional time off.
Additional information about eligibility under the FFCRA can be found on the Department of Labor website here.

dialog_nodes.title: What is the role of the World Health Organization?

values.text: The World Health Organization (WHO) is an international organization to help combat disease within the United Nations system. You can find out more about WHO at who.int.

dialog_nodes.title: How can I apply for unemployment?

values.text:
In order to file for unemployment insurance, you will need to check your eligibility and apply for benefits on your state's labor website. The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) expands eligibility in certain cases where unemployment is directly related to the Covid-19 outbreak.
For more information on how to apply, please refer to the Department of Labor guidance here.

dialog_nodes.title: How can I help others affected by the coronavirus?

values.text:
There are many ways to help out during this crisis. If you know someone who is elderly or at high risk of complications with Covid-19, you can offer to help them with groceries or other necessities. You can also volunteer to help out at a local food bank.
If you are a health care professional, you may also be able to help out on the front lines, as many hospitals are facing staffing shortages as a result of the quick escalation of Covid-19. You can reach out to local hospitals to see if they are accepting volunteers or hiring.
In addition to volunteering, there is significant need for the following donations:
  • Food items
  • Cleaning supplies
  • Toilet paper
  • Hand Sanitizer
  • Money
  • Blood

Many hospitals are also struggling to keep up their stock of personal protective equipment (PPE). If you have any of the following unopened and unused items, consider donating them to a local hospital:
  • N95 masks
  • Surgical masks
  • Face shields and protective eyewear
  • Disposable gloves

dialog_nodes.title: What does a national emergency mean?

values.text:
On March 13, 2020 a national emergency was declared in the United States. This was done to free up funds that could be used to help combat the Covid-19 outbreak. Similarly, many states and counties have issued their own state of emergency declarations to ease access to federal funds and resources to combat the outbreak at the local level.
For more information on the response of the United States government to the Covid-19 outbreak, visit usa.gov.

values: What is the age of the person of concern ?

values.text: What is your age ?

If you have fever, cough, or shortness of breath, call your healthcare provider. They may tell you to manage your care from home. If so, follow these tips.
If you develop emergency warning signs for COVID-19 get medical attention immediately. Emergency warning signs include*:
-Trouble breathing -Persistent pain or pressure in the chest -New confusion or inability to arouse -Bluish lips or face *This list is not all inclusive. Please consult your medical provider for any other symptoms that are severe or concerning.
For more information on caring for yourself at home, visit here.

Shortness of breath refers to difficulty breathing. The Mayo clinic has a definition here.
For more information about symptoms of COVID-19, visit here.

dialog_nodes.title: What happens when the hospital is full?

values.text:
Listen to and follow the directions of your state and local authorities.
Not all patients with COVID-19 require hospital admission. Patients whose clinical presentation warrants in-patient clinical management for supportive medical care should be admitted to the hospital under appropriate isolation precautions.
The decision to monitor these patients in the inpatient or outpatient setting should be made on a case-by-case basis. This decision will depend not only on the clinical presentation, but also on the patient’s ability to engage in self-monitoring, the feasibility of safe isolation at home, and the risk of transmission in the patient’s home environment.
For more information visit here or here .

dialog_nodes.title: Is there a vaccine for COVID-19?

values.text:
To date, there is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat COVID-2019. However, those affected should receive care to relieve symptoms. People with serious illness should be hospitalized. Most patients recover thanks to supportive care.
Possible vaccines and some specific drug treatments are under investigation. They are being tested through clinical trials. WHO is coordinating efforts to develop vaccines and medicines to prevent and treat COVID-19.
The most effective ways to protect yourself and others against COVID-19 are to frequently clean your hands, cover your cough with the bend of elbow or tissue, and maintain a distance of at least 1 meter (3 feet) from people who are coughing or sneezing. For more information visit the World Heath Organization's website.
A pandemic is an outbreak that has spread globally and can not be easily tracked or contained. The CDC has more information on why Covid-19 is a pandemic and what that means here.

dialog_nodes.title: What should I do if I'm studying abroad?

values.text:
If you are currently studying abroad, you should work with the program administrator to determine next steps and, if applicable, find out how they plan to facilitate your return home. The CDC is recommending that all institutes of higher education consider postponing or cancelling their study abroad programs.
If you do opt to return to the United States, you may need to stay home for 14 days and avoid all contact with others. You can find more information about returning from international travel on the CDC's website here.

dialog_nodes.title: What should I do if I'm a teacher?

values.text:
If you are a teacher at a school, you should follow the guidance given by the school's administration as well as check out the CDC's checklist for teachers.
For school administrators, the CDC has answers to many frequently asked questions as well as guidance on planning and reacting to the coronavirus outbreak.

dialog_nodes.title: When are schools opening back up?

values.text:
Many schools have been closed due to the Covid-19 outbreak with no definitive date for reopening. For information specific to your school, you should contact the school's administration or visit their website.
The CDC has also provided helpful guidance for parents of school-age children with answers to frequently asked questions as well as how to care for and talk to children about the outbreak.

dialog_nodes.title: Can I still go for a walk outside?

values.text:
Generally, it is okay to go outside to walk, run, and bike so long as you avoid contact with others. You should visit your local government website to ensure that these activities are permitted.
The combination of being stuck at home and dealing with the Covid-19 outbreak may be stressful for some. The CDC has helpful guidance for coping with stress related to the outbreak.

dialog_nodes.title: Is it safe to attend any events?

values.text:
The general recommendation is to avoid gatherings of more than 10 people. Because of this restriction, many large events have been canceled or postponed.
If you are organizing a large gathering or event, you should refer to the CDC guidelines for organizing mass gatherings.

dialog_nodes.title: Should I wear a mask in public?

values.text:
The CDC recommends wearing a cloth face covering in public settings where social distancing may be difficult to maintain. Please refer to the CDC web site for more information on face coverings and general guidance on protecting yourself and others.
Healthcare workers caring for patients suspected to have Covid-19 also need to wear face-masks to prevent additional spread of Covid-19.
If you have a surplus of N95 masks or surgical masks, consider donating them to a local hospital.

dialog_nodes.title: Where can I buy a mask?

values.text:
Manufacturers around the world are working hard to produce more face-masks and supply them to hospitals as quickly as possible. Because hospitals are in short-supply, they are taking precedence over orders to supply the retail market.
If you are sick and need a face-mask to prevent spreading the illness to others, the CDC recommends improvising with a scarf or a bandana if you do not have or cannot purchase a face-mask.
In the last 14 days, <? $self == True ? "have you": "has the person of concern" ?> been exposed to a COVID-19 person?

Answer 'Yes' if any of the following are true:
  • Live with someone who has COVID-19
  • Had close contact with someone who has COVID-19 (for 10 minutes, I was within 6 feet or 2 meters of someone who’s sick or exposed to a cough or sneeze)
  • Been near someone who has COVID-19 (I was at least 6 feet or 2 meters away or more and was not exposed to a sneeze or cough)

Over the past 14 DAYS, <? $self == True ? "have you": "has the person of concern" ?> had any of the following high-risk travel history?
<li>Travel to High-Risk or CDC Level 3 Countries
<li>Travel Domestically Out-of-State
<li>Cruise Ship Travel

dialog_nodes.title: Who are you?  What can you do?

values.text: I'm a virtual assistant powered by IBM Watson Assistant Service on IBM Cloud. I can answer questions about travel restrictions, symptoms, testing, and a few other topics as well!
Hello! I'm happy to answer your questions about Covid-19. I can answer questions about travel restrictions, symptoms, testing, and a few other topics as well!

:
  • Living in nursing home or long-term facility
  • Working or volunteering in a healthcare facility or care facility
  • Pregnant or Breastfeeding
  • Homeless
<? $self == True ? "Do you": "Does the person of concern" ?>  have any of these medical conditions?

• Serious heart conditions (e.g., Coronary artery disease, uncontrolled hypertension, congestive heart failure)
  • Diabetes
  • Chronic kidney disease undergoing dialysis
  • Liver disease (e.g., Cirrhosis, Fatty Liver Disease)
  • Severe obesity (Body Mass Index of 40 or higher)
  • Active Cancer
  • HIV/AIDS
  • Immunocompromised (e.g., bone marrow or organ transplant recipient, prolonged use of corticosteroids or other immune weakening medications)
Source: CDC, WHO, Dynamed COVID-19

dialog_nodes.title: What is the mortality rate for Covid-19?

values.text: The CDC updates their tracking on a daily basis. In order to get the most up to date information you should check the CDC website

dialog_nodes.title: How is Covid different from other illnesses?

values.text: The World Health Organization's Director-General gave a great overview of the differences between Covid and many commonly known illnesses, you can read all kinds of interesting details in the summary.
If you feel that you have any symptoms indicating Covid-19 you should call your healthcare professional immediately.

dialog_nodes.title: Can Covid be transferred through packages?

values.text: It may be possible that a person can get COVID-19 by touching a surface or object that has the virus on it and then touching their own mouth, nose, or possibly their eyes, but this is not thought to be the main way the virus spreads. See other ways to Covid-19 can spread on the CDC website.

dialog_nodes.title: What are the symptoms of Covid-19?

values.text:
According to the CDC, reported illnesses have ranged from mild symptoms to severe illness and death for confirmed coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) cases. These symptoms may appear 2-14 days after exposure (based on the incubation period of MERS-CoV viruses).
  • Fever
  • Cough
  • Shortness of breath
  • Chills
  • Repeated shaking with chills
  • Muscle pain
  • Headache
  • Sore throat
  • Loss of taste or smell
The CDC provides great information on how to clean and disinfect your home. They are always updating their information, so you should check out their site .
They recommend that you always wear gloves, and that most EPA rated household disinfectants should get the job done!
The virus is thought to spread mainly from person to person. The CDC website is continually updated with many important details about Covid-19 and how it spreads.

dialog_nodes.title: How long does the virus last?

values.text: Symptoms for Covid-19 typically appear 2-14 days after contracting the virus. You should contact your healthcare professional at the first sign of symptoms.

On February 11, 2020 the World Health Organization announced an official name for the disease that is causing the 2019 novel coronavirus outbreak, first identified in Wuhan China. The new name of this disease is coronavirus disease 2019, abbreviated as COVID-19. In COVID-19, ‘CO’ stands for ‘corona,’ ‘VI’ for ‘virus,’ and ‘D’ for disease. Formerly, this disease was referred to as “2019 novel coronavirus” or “2019-nCoV”.

There are many types of human coronaviruses including some that commonly cause mild upper-respiratory tract illnesses. COVID-19 is a new disease, caused be a novel (or new) coronavirus that has not previously been seen in humans. The name of this disease was selected following the World Health Organization (WHO) best practice for naming of new human infectious diseases.

dialog_nodes.title: Am I at risk to get Covid-19?

values.text: According to the CDC:

COVID-19 is a new disease and there is limited information regarding risk factors for severe disease. Based on currently available information and clinical expertise, older adults and people of any age who have serious underlying medical conditions might be at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19. Based upon available information to date, those at high-risk for severe illness from COVID-19 include:
  • People aged 65 years and older
  • People who live in a nursing home or long-term care facility
Other high-risk conditions could include:
  • People with chronic lung disease or moderate to severe asthma
  • People who have heart disease with complications
  • People who are immunocompromised including cancer treatment
  • People of any age with severe obesity (body mass index [(BM]I)≥40) or certain underlying medical conditions, particularly if not well controlled, such as those with diabetes, renal failure, or liver disease might also be at risk
  • People who are pregnant should be monitored since they are known to be at risk with severe viral illness, however, to date data on COVID-19 has not shown increased risk

According to the CDC website there is no evidence that animals play a significant role in spreading the virus that causes COVID-19, although a small number of animals have been reported to have been infected with this virus.

dialog_nodes.title: Can I go to the grocery store?

values.text: You are allowed to go and buy essential items as needed, but there are many precautions you can take along the way to limit your exposure as much as possible. It is not recommended to go during busy times or shopping for any items that are not a necessity.

dialog_nodes.title: Number of cases in my area

values.text: You can view the number of cases anywhere in the world on the weather.com Covid-19 page

dialog_nodes.title: 2. Self-Isolate, No Testing, and No Immediate Access to Healthcare Professional Recommended

values.text: Self-Isolate, No Testing, and No Immediate Access to Healthcare Professional Recommended
Per CDC, if you had high-risk travel and no symptoms, you should isolate for 14 days. If you develop symptoms, you may need testing.

dialog_nodes.title: 3. Testing and/or Access to Healthcare Professional Recommended

values.text: Call your healthcare provider and tell them about your symptoms and your exposure. They will decide whether you need to be tested. \n\nKeep in mind that there is no treatment for COVID-19 and people who are mildly ill may be able to isolate and care for themselves at home. For more information, visit the CDC website
It is recommended that you call 911 in order to seek immediate medical attention. If you think you may have these symptoms connected to COVID-19, then please make sure to tell the 911 operator.
<? $self == True ? "Do you": "Does the person of concern" ?> have any of the following Red-Flag symptoms?

• Severe Difficulty Breathing
  • Severe Confusion or Altered Level of Consciousness
  • Difficulty Speaking, Face Drooping or Arm/Leg Weakness
  • Chest Pain
  • Severe Abdominal Pain

dialog_nodes.title: How can I get a coronavirus test?

values.text:
The process and locations for testing vary from place to place. Contact your state, local, tribal, or territorial department for more information, or reach out to a medical provider. For more information about testing, see the CDC's guidelines on Testing for COVID-19 .
You can find a list of State and Local Health Departments here or by looking up your state here.

dialog_nodes.title: Do I need to get tested?

values.text:
Not everyone needs to be tested for COVID-19.
The process and locations for testing vary from place to place. Contact your state, local, tribal, or territorial department for more information, or reach out to a medical provider. For more information about testing, see the CDC's guidelines on Testing for COVID-19 .
You can find a list of State and Local Health Departments here or by looking up your state here.
If you develop emergency warning signs for COVID-19 get medical attention immediately. Emergency warning signs include*:
-Trouble breathing -Persistent pain or pressure in the chest -New confusion or inability to arouse -Bluish lips or face
*This list is not all inclusive. Please consult your medical provider for any other symptoms that are severe or concerning.
For more information visit here.

dialog_nodes.title: I am currently traveling out of the country. Who should I contact?

values.text:
Follow the CDC's guidelines for all travel. You can find travel recommendations by country as well as a Geographic Risk Assessment map for COVID-19 transmission here.
You can find a list of State and Local Health Departments here or by looking up your state here.

dialog_nodes.title: Can I return to the United States?

values.text:
If you are returning to the US from international travel, the CDC recommends following these guidelines.
Stay home for 14 days from the time you returned from international travel. During this 14-day period, take these steps to monitor your health and practice social distancing:
-Take your temperature with a thermometer two times a day and monitor for fever. Also watch for cough or trouble breathing. -Stay home and avoid contact with others. Do not go to work or school. -Do not take public transportation, taxis, or ride-shares. Keep your distance from others (about 6 feet or 2 meters).
For more information on travel restrictions, visit here.

dialog_nodes.title: Are there any travel restrictions in place yet?

values.text: Follow the CDC's guidelines for all travel. You can find travel restrictions by country as well as a Geographic Risk Assessment map for COVID-19 transmission here.
